newsitem.title: USA: FBI calls off truck hunt after false alarm.
newsitem.headline: FBI calls off truck hunt after false alarm.

text.p: A nationwide police hunt for a rental truck feared to be carrying bomb-making material was called off on Tuesday after FBI agents found the vehicle in Atlanta and said the alert had been a false alarm.
Two men using the truck were interviewed by Federal Bureau of Investigation agents and released after proving they had legitimate business, officials said.

"The FBI and ATF (Bureau of Alcohol, Tobacco and Firearms) now believe, based upon their interviews and a search of the U-Haul truck, that there is no substance to the fears that two men driving the U-Haul truck were accumulating materials to build a bomb," the FBI said in a a statement.

The nationwide search began on Saturday after a man in Haltom City, Texas, reported seeing three white men fill up large containers with 30 gallons (113 litres) of diesel fuel and load them onto a U-Haul truck already packed with up to 4,500 pounds (2,041 kg) of ammonium nitrate fertiliser.
Those same ingredients were used in the bomb which wrecked the Alfred P. Murrah federal building in Oklahoma City on April 19, 1995, killing 168 people.
But FBI officials said the men in the U-Haul truck ran a cleaning business and had loaded it with cleaning supplies, not fertiliser.
"It did look bad at first but it all makes sense when you look at who they were and what they were doing," spokeswoman Marjorie Poche said.
